data.title: Largest Square
data.solution:
s = int(input())
n = int(input())
v = int(input())

persons = 0
usedSpace = 0

for i in range(v):
    d = int(input())
    # calculate how many persons fit in this division
    persons += (d * n) // s
    usedSpace += d
    
# check remaining space    
persons += (n - usedSpace) * n // s

print(persons)
data.statement:
You're given a square building of NxN area with a number of parallel walls. Provided that each person needs a certain area to do their work, and no person can spread themselves between two rooms, calculate how many people can work in the building.
Walls themselves don't take any space. People only care about the amount of surface available, not the actual dimensions.
`+--+--+
|  |  |
|  |  |
|  |  |
|  |  |
+--+--+`
The 4x4 square buliding is divided in two 2x4 rooms by parallel walls
If the space for a person is 3 area, only two persons can work in each room, for a total of 4.
data.stubGenerator:
read S:int
read N:int
read V:int
loop V read d:int
write persons
data.inputDescription:
<<Line 1:>> An integer [[S]] for the amount of area each person needs to work
<<Line 2:>> An integer [[N]] for the length of the sides of the square building.
<<Line 3:>> An integer [[V]] for the number of walls that divide the square building into V+1 rooms.
<<Next [[V]] lines:>> An integer [[D]] which denotes the distance from one wall to the next, starting from the west wall of the building.
data.outputDescription: The total number of persons that can work in the rooms.

lastVersion.statementHTML:
Goal

You're given a square building of NxN area with a number of parallel walls. Provided that each person needs a certain area to do their work, and no person can spread themselves between two rooms, calculate how many people can work in the building.
Walls themselves don't take any space. People only care about the amount of surface available, not the actual dimensions.
+--+--+
|  |  |
|  |  |
|  |  |
|  |  |
+--+--+

The 4x4 square buliding is divided in two 2x4 rooms by parallel walls
If the space for a person is 3 area, only two persons can work in each room, for a total of 4.
Input
Line 1: An integer S for the amount of area each person needs to work
Line 2: An integer N for the length of the sides of the square building.
Line 3: An integer V for the number of walls that divide the square building into V+1 rooms.
Next V lines: An integer D which denotes the distance from one wall to the next, starting from the west wall of the building.
Output
The total number of persons that can work in the rooms.
Constraints
1 ≤ S ≤ 100
1 ≤ N ≤ 1000
1 ≤ V ≤ 100
1 ≤ D ≤ 100
Example
Input
3
4
1
2
Output
4
